I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of Viet Nam (the Government) requested the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) and other development partners for technical assistance (TA) to undertake a detailed 
review of the water sector (the Review). The design and scope of the Review have been 
developed  through  a  series  of  meetings  between  the  Government  and  representatives  of 
external funding agencies involved in Viet Nam’s water sector from October 2005 to September 
2006. The TA design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.1 ADB was requested by the 
Government and its development partners to coordinate the TA. ADB reached an understanding 
with  the  Government  on  the  TA’s  expected  impact,  outcome,  outputs,  implementation 
arrangements, cost estimates, financing arrangements, and terms of reference for consulting 
services in December 2006. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Viet Nam has achieved remarkable economic growth2 and reductions in poverty over the 
last decade, from about 58.1% in 1993, to 23.2% in 2004, and an estimated 22.0% in 2005. 
Gross domestic product (GDP) per capita increased from $288 in 1993 to $622 in 2005, with a 
marginal increase in inequality. Strong economic growth has been accompanied by increasingly 
rapid urbanization and significant increases in wages and quality of life. However, this growth 
has included some less positive changes, such as high rural–urban migration, and is placing 
heavy pressures on the country’s dilapidated infrastructure and fragile natural resource base.  
 
3.  Although Viet Nam is a high rainfall country, averaging 1,940 millimeters per year, it is 
not rich in water. Increasing competition for reliable water resources may constrain economic 
growth and the creation of livelihood opportunities. Currently, average annual per capita surface 
water availability is about 3,840 cubic meters (m3),3 based on water resources generated within 
national borders. Viet Nam can be considered a water deficient nation and is predicted to face 
increasingly difficult challenges with water resources in the near future. Allowing for projected 
population  growth  and  taking  the  expected  impacts  of  climate  change  into  consideration, 
average annual per capita surface water availability will be approximately 2,830 m3 by 2025. 
Cross-border river flows increase the projected water availability to about 7,660 m3 per capita, 
but this figure disguises substantial seasonal and spatial disparities. Droughts are frequent and 
prolonged, and nearly two thirds of the surface water inflows from neighboring countries are 
concentrated in the Mekong River delta.  
4.  Demands for water resources are growing rapidly, not just for extraction but also to 
increase hydropower generation to satisfy the expanding economy and growing population. 
Groundwater is increasingly used in both rural areas and major urban centers, but groundwater 
levels are falling dramatically in some areas, resulting in land subsidence and damage to 
infrastructure. Some groundwater sources have elevated levels of arsenic.  
5.  The crucial role of water in the nation’s sustainable development, human health, and life 
has not always been fully appreciated; its value as a scarce natural resource and economic 
good has not always been recognized. As a result, the protection and management of water 
resources  has  not  been  given  adequate  attention.  An  earlier  review  of  Viet  Nam’s  water 
resources  in  1995–1996  helped  identify  problems  and  the  range  of  options  available  to

6.  The water sector still faces substantial challenges, including (i) increasing competition 
for  heavily  committed  freshwater  resources;  (ii)  increasing  pollution  of  rivers  by  industrial, 
municipal,  and  agricultural  sources;  (iii)  increasingly  severe  and  frequent  natural  disasters 
affecting  a  rising  population  living  in  disaster-prone  areas.  These  challenges  highlight  the 
urgency for the Government to complete sector reforms to separate the tasks of regulation, 
delivery of services, and policy leadership in the water sector. Groundwater is being extracted at 
unsustainable rates; few water service providers operate in a financially viable way; much of the 
existing water management infrastructure is in poor repair and needs to be replaced; and most 
suitable land is already under irrigation with diminishing opportunities for increasing production. 
Furthermore, development of basic water services has not kept pace with economic growth, 
leaving around one third of the population without adequate water supplies and two thirds of the 
population without sanitation. Viet Nam is on target to meet Millennium Development Goal 
(MDG) 10 (halving the number of persons without access to safe water and sanitation in urban 
areas) but progress in rural areas remains behind target.5 
 
7.  The Government has made substantial progress in water sector reforms since 1995. 
Specific reforms include (i) passage of a water law in 1998;6 (ii) establishment of the Ministry of 
Natural Resources and Environment (MONRE) in 2002;7 (iii) establishment of the National 
Water Resources Council (NWRC), chaired by the deputy prime minister,8 as the water sector 
apex body; and (iv) adoption of the sustainability concepts reflected in the (a) National Strategy 
for  Environmental  Protection;  (b)  Strategic  Orientation  for  Sustainable  Development 
(Agenda 21); (c) National Water Resources Strategy (NWRS);9 (d) Law on Water Resources; 
(e) Law on Environmental Protection; and (f) adoption of a rural water supply and sanitation 
strategy following the multi-funding agency review of the subsector in 2005. These actions 
signal an important shift toward recognition of the importance of a sustainable and healthy 
natural resource base. Such recognition is a critical ingredient in the Government's efforts to 
achieve sustainable socioeconomic development, and is fully consistent with the ADB water 
policy.10  
 
8.  In its NWRS, the Government defined the main objectives for the water sector in the 
next 15 years as the protection, efficient exploitation, and sustainable development of water 
resources  on  the  basis  of  integrated  and  unified  water  resources  management.  The 
Government  intends  to  meet  water  demands  for  people’s  living  and  socioeconomic 
development, while ensuring national defense, national security, and environmental protection 
as the country’s industrialisation and modernisation proceed. The Government is encouraging 
proactive prevention to control and mitigate the adverse impacts of water-related disasters, 
while developing multisector industries that utilize water resources. Viet Nam places high priority 
on improved international cooperation and the harmonious sharing of water resources.

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The TA will help the Government and its development partners review the current state 
of the water sector—including urban, rural, and basin water subsectors11—and adopt integrated 
water resources management (IWRM) principles in line with its NWRS objectives. The impact of 
the TA will be increased contribution of water resources management to poverty reduction and 
sustainable  national  development.  Its  outcome  will  be  a  common  framework  to  guide 
development decisions in the water resources sector in Viet Nam over the coming 10 years. The 
framework will represent a shared vision for cooperation in the sector. The TA will establish a 
foundation for further strengthening of the policy, regulatory, and institutional framework for 
improved IWRM planning and implementation at the national and local levels. The framework 
will represent a consensus on the water sector among different government agencies and 
stakeholders from the external funding agencies, nongovernment organizations (NGOs), and 
the private sector.  
 
10.  The TA will generate a better understanding of the potential contribution of the water 
sector  to  the  achievement  of  the  goals  and  targets  of  the  2006–2010  Socio-Economic 
Development Plan (SEDP), which aims to ensure balanced poverty reduction, economic growth, 
and environmental sustainability. The TA outputs will (i) clarify the delineation of functions 
among national, provincial, and local agencies; and (ii) strengthen the capacity for IWRM in 
agencies responsible for planning, management, and regulation of water resources. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The TA will adopt a holistic and inclusive approach, encompassing (i) consultation with 
relevant  stakeholders,  including  government  agencies  at  central  and  provincial  levels, 
international development partners, and the NGO community; (ii) compilation of available data, 
analysis of previous reviews,12 and derivation of water sector characteristics and trends; and 
(iii) workshop discussions. It will draw on the extensive range of existing reviews, databases, 
and  studies  on  different  aspects  of  water  resources  management,  poverty  reduction, 
sustainable development, and environmental management in Viet Nam.  
 
12.  The TA will be implemented in four phases: 
 
(i)  An inception phase, during which detailed methodology and an implementation 
plan will be prepared. This phase will culminate in an inception report to be 
submitted  for  consideration  by  the  task  force13 within  1  month  of  consultant 
mobilization. 
(ii)  An assessment of the sector status, which will analyze the water balance in 
major basins and provinces as the basis for a review of current water use and 
trends in terms of water quantity (river flows and groundwater); water quality; 
socioeconomic conditions; water demands present and future; international water 
basin considerations; environmental values and conditions; legal, policy, and 
institutional  arrangements  at  all  levels  (including  resources,  systems,  and 
capacity); water management experiences from previous programs and projects;

(iii)  The  identification  of  key  sector  management  and  development  issues  and 
feasible options to address them. An issues and options report will set out the 
advantages and disadvantages of available options. 
(iv)  Consultations on the issues and options report will enable identification of a 
consolidated set of recommendations that will be reviewed in a multi-stakeholder 
workshop. The final recommendations will be integrated into the TA final report, 
which will include a summary of the outputs from each phase.  
  
13.  The TA will include site visits to selected project locations in the provinces and rapid 
appraisal fieldwork to verify data and collect supporting information at key sites. Fieldwork is 
likely to include an assessment of the role of water management in the livelihoods of poor rural 
communities  in  different  parts  of  the  country  and,  subject  to  resource  constraints,  an 
assessment of the effectiveness of irrigation management companies and the potential role of 
the private sector in water resources management. Thematic studies of key issues, where 
knowledge gaps are identified, will be prepared with the assistance of appropriate national 
research and policy development institutions. 
 
14.  The TA’s outputs will be assessments of (i) achievements and present status of the 
water sector in Viet Nam, including knowledge of water resources and trends in water use, 
availability, sustainability over recent years, and challenges and issues; (ii) diagnostic analysis 
of the policy, regulatory, and institutional framework for water resources management, including 
progress  toward  achieving  IWRM  and  the  relationship  of  water  resources  management  to 
Viet Nam’s wider policy goals; and (iii) options and recommendations for future water sector 
development,  management,  and  sustainable  financing  including  investment  priorities  and 
sequencing. The findings of (i) and (ii) will be documented in the status report. An issues and 
options report will be prepared to facilitate consultation for identifying recommendations. The 
final report, in English and Vietnamese, will include findings and recommendations of (iii).  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The total TA costs are estimated at $830,000 equivalent, of which (i) $310,000 will be 
financed on a grant basis by ADB's TA funding program, (ii) $160,000 will be financed on a 
grant basis by the Government of the Netherlands, (iii) $60,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by the Government of Australia, and (iv) $50,000 will be financed on a grant basis by the 
Government of Denmark. Financing by the governments of the Netherlands, Australia, and 
Denmark will be administered by ADB. The Government of Viet Nam will provide counterpart 
contributions totaling $50,000, in kind. The Cooperation Fund for the Water Sector, through an 
approved TA,14 will finance the remaining $200,000 equivalent. Detailed cost estimates and the 
financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  ADB will be the Executing Agency for the TA. The NWRC will be the Implementing 
Agency. The NWRC office15 will support the TA on a day-to-day basis, and a TA office16 will be

established at the Department of Water Resources Management in MONRE. The Government 
will  establish  a  task  force  under  the  NWRC,  including  representatives  of  appropriate 
government agencies, development partners, and NGOs. The chair of the task force will be 
responsible for obtaining all necessary government clearances. The task force will (i) facilitate 
access to all relevant data and information, (ii) assure counterpart inputs, (iii) guide the TA, 
(iv) assess its outputs, and (v) approve all reports and recommendations. 
  
17.  The TA will be carried out over 8 months from April to November 2007. The TA will 
finance a team of international and national consultants to help the task force carry out the 
Review. ADB, as coordinator for the development partners, will provide overall supervision of 
the team and administer the TA. The consultants will provide 69.5 person-months of national 
and  14.5  person-months  of international consultant inputs.17 The  international  water  sector 
specialist will be team leader, managing the TA in close collaboration with NWRC. Expertise will 
be required in water policy and institutions, natural resource and development economics, water 
supply and sanitation, irrigation, water resources, groundwater, water quality, sociology, disaster 
management,  industrial  water  management,  environment,  energy,  river  navigation,  data 
management,  and  monitoring  and  evaluation.  ADB  will  select  and  engage  the  firm  of 
international and national consultants using the quality and cost-based selection method and 
simplified technical proposals, in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2006, as amended from time to time). The outline terms of reference for the consultants are in 
Appendix 3. All equipment for the TA will be procured in accordance with ADB's Procurement 
Guidelines (2006, as amended from time to time), and will be transferred to the Executing 
Agency upon TA completion. 
 
18.  The inception report will be presented within 1 month of the start of the TA. The draft 
status report will be prepared within 3 months of the start of the TA. It will be presented at a 
national workshop after a suitable review period. The final status report will be presented within 
1 month of the workshop. The issues and options report will be submitted for review 2 months 
after the final status report has been submitted. It will form the basis for consultations with 
relevant stakeholders on the recommendations. The draft final report will be prepared 3 months 
after the issues and options report has been submitted, and will be presented at a national 
workshop  after  a  suitable  review  period.  The  final  report,  including  an  agreed  set  of 
recommendations, will be presented within 1 month of the final national workshop. The draft 
table of contents is in Appendix 4.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $160,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Government of the Netherlands; (ii) ADB administering a 
portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $60,000 to be financed on a 
grant  basis  by  the  Government  of  Australia;  (iii)  ADB  administering  a  portion  of  technical 
assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $50,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the 
Government of Denmark; and (iv) ADB providing the balance not exceeding the equivalent of 
$310,000 on a grant basis to the Government of Viet Nam for the Viet Nam Water Sector 
Review, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Introduction 
1.  The  Water  Sector  Review  (the  Review)  aims  to  prepare  a  common  framework  for 
guiding development of the water resources sector in Viet Nam over the coming 5–10 year 
period. Its scope will include (i) review of the present status of the water sector in Viet Nam, 
including trends in water use, availability, and sustainability over recent years; (ii) analysis of the 
policy,  regulatory,  and  institutional  framework  for  water  resources  management,  including 
progress  toward  achieving  integrated  water  resources  management  (IWRM);  and  (iii) 
development  of  options  for  future  management  and  water  sector  development,  including 
investment priorities and sequence. The Review will generate a better understanding of the 
potential contribution of the water sector to the achievement of the goals and targets of the 
2006–2010 Socio-Economic Development Plan (SEDP).1 
 
2.  The National Water Resources Council (NWRC) as implementing agency will create a 
task force2 to guide the Review, represent the interests of relevant agencies at both national 
and provincial levels, and ensure that the Government’s policies and development strategies 
are accurately reflected in its outcomes. Representatives of the funding agency group and 
national and international nongovernment organizations (NGOs) will be in the task force.  
 
3.  The  implementation  of  the  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  require  the  services  of  a 
multidisciplinary team of international and national consultants. A consulting firm, or association 
of firms, will be engaged to provide these services and work closely with the counterpart staff of 
the TA task force: a total of 84.0 person-months of services from international (14.5 person-
months)  and  national  (69.5  person-months)  consultants  will  be  required.  The  international 
consultants will have expertise in (i) water policy/institutions and team leadership, (ii) natural 
resource and development economics, and (iii) disaster management. The World Bank has 
selected  and  mobilized  an  international  irrigation  specialist  (5  person-months),  who  has 
commenced work on the Review and will report directly to the team leader when the consultants 
are fielded. The national consultants will include a deputy team leader with expertise in water 
resources. Other national consultants will have expertise in (i) water resources, (ii) groundwater, 
(iii)  water  quality,  (iv)  rural  sociology,  (v)  disaster  management,  (vi)  industrial  water 
management, (vii) economics, (viii) environment, (ix) energy, (x) river navigation, (xi) water 
supply and sanitation, (xii) Geographic Information Systems (GIS) and data management, and 
(xii) monitoring and evaluation.

and competitiveness; (ii) move strongly toward a market economy, and develop market institutions; (iii) accelerate 
international economic integration to boost trade and inflows of capital and technology; (iv) develop science and 
technology,  reform  education  and  training,  and  improve  the  management  of  natural  resources  and  the 
environment; (v) build cultural foundations and significantly improve people’s health; (vi) ensure social equity, 
create jobs and wealth, eliminate hunger, reduce poverty, and provide a social security system; (vii) continue to 
build a socialist state ruled by law, and reform public administration to reduce bureaucracy, corruption and waste, 
and harassment of the people; and (viii) strengthen national defense, security, and foreign relations. 
2  Participating  government  institutions  will  include  the  ministries  of  natural  resources  and  the  environment, 
agriculture and rural development, planning and investment, transport, industry, and construction; Institute for 
Water  Resources  Planning;  and  National  Water  Resources  Council.  Development  partners  include  Agence 
Française de Développement, Asian Development Bank, the embassies of Denmark and Sweden, Japan Bank for 
International Cooperation, Japan International Cooperation Agency, Royal Netherlands Embassy, United Nations 
Children's  Fund  (UNICEF),  United  Nations  Development  Programme,  United  Nations  Food  and  Agricultural 
Organization, and World Bank. Various nongovernment organizations will participate.

10  Appendix 3 
4.  It is expected that the Review will take place over 8 months from April to November 
2007. 
 
B.  Background 
5.  The last water resources sector review for Viet Nam was prepared in 1995. Since then, 
the environment governing the sector has significantly changed. Of particular relevance are the 
(i) promulgation of the Water Resources Law in 1998; (ii) creation of the Ministry of Natural 
Resources and Environment in 2002; (iii) introduction of a range of new laws and decrees on 
issues,  such  as  licensing  and  pollution  control;  and  (iv)  introduction  of  policies  related  to 
decentralization and grassroots democracy. Over the last 5 years, Viet Nam’s economic growth 
has averaged more than 7% and overall poverty has been reduced from 58% in 1993 to 24% in 
2004. This has had a large impact on the demands for water and has brought environmental 
sustainability to the forefront of issues affecting water resources management.  
 
6.  Viet Nam faces a number of challenges in the field of water resources management. In 
the rural sector, many irrigation systems suffer from low efficiency, and their management by 
irrigation management companies is not cost-effective. Non-irrigation uses of water in rural 
production are widely neglected in development programs. Systematic challenges remain in the 
water supply, sanitation, and health field despite recent reforms. Natural disasters are a concern 
in many parts of Viet Nam, with flash floods, landslides, and coastal erosion common in coastal 
areas.  Water  shortages  occur  frequently  during  the  dry  season,  and  saltwater  intrusion  is 
advancing into coastal plains and delta areas, limiting opportunities for extraction of water for 
agricultural, domestic, and industrial uses. The high regional, seasonal, and annual variability of 
water supply is likely to become more extreme because of climate change associated with 
global warming. Pollution of surface and groundwater is emerging as a problem in many river 
basins because of population growth and rapid industrialization. 
 
7.  The water sector in Viet Nam is characterized by a fragmented policy and institutional 
framework, with a wide range of policies affecting the sector and a history of poor coordination 
among ministries such as the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development, Ministry of Natural 
Resources  and  Environment,  Ministry  of  Construction,  and  Ministry  of  Health.  There  are 
particular concerns over responsibilities for river basin planning and IWRM. Links to wider 
national  poverty  reduction,  economic  development,  and  institutional  reform  policies  and 
processes (including decentralization, Comprehensive Poverty Reduction and Growth Strategy, 
socialization, and 5-year planning system) are also poorly developed, so the full developmental 
impacts of water management are often not realized. 
 
8.  At the same time, the Government provides substantial investment funds for irrigation, 
flood protection, and hydropower development. National poverty reduction programs, such as 
Program  135  and  the  Rural  Water  Supply  and  Sanitation  Program,  also  include  large 
investments  in  water  services.  There  have  been  a  number  of  reform  initiatives,  including 
establishing river basin organizations, introduction of participatory irrigation management, and 
development of province-level water strategies. However, to date, these have been limited in 
scale and impact and are yet to be adopted nationwide. 
 
9.  Sustaining economic growth in Viet Nam will require continuing investment in the water 
sector. One of the central aims of the Review will be to provide systematic and coherent 
justification and direction for such investments. This will be achieved through assessment of 
experience  and  analysis  of  future  options.  The  relationship  of  such  investments  to  wider

Appendix 3  11 
development processes, and the policy and institutional changes needed to make investments 
more effective, will also be examined. 
 
C.  Consultant Inputs and Time Planning 
10.  The Review will be implemented in four phases: 
 
(i)  An  inception  phase,  during  which  team  members  are  mobilized,  institutional 
arrangements  are  consolidated,  and  a  more  detailed  methodology  and 
implementation plan is prepared based on detailed consultations with relevant 
stakeholders. This phase will culminate in an inception report. 
(ii)  An assessment of the sector status, which will analyze the water balance in 
major basins and provinces as the basis for a review of current water use and 
trends in terms of water quantity (river flows and groundwater), water quality, 
socioeconomic conditions; water demands present and future; international water 
basin considerations; environmental values and conditions; legal, policy, and 
institutional  arrangements  at  all  levels  (including  resources,  systems,  and 
capacity); water management experiences from previous programs and projects; 
and a preliminary analysis of the economic significance of water at household 
and national levels. This assessment will be reviewed in a multi-stakeholder 
workshop and consolidated into a sector status report. 
(iii)  The identification of key sector management and development issues and the 
consideration of all feasible options to address these issues will be consolidated 
into an issues and options report that will set out in a balanced manner the pros 
and cons of all the options considered. 
(iv)  Consultations on the issues and options report will enable identification of a 
consolidated set of recommendations that will be reviewed in a multi-stakeholder 
workshop and through direct consultations. The final recommendations will be 
integrated into the review final report which will include a summary of the outputs 
from the earlier phases. Appendix 4 provides the expected contents of the final 
report. 
 
D.  International Consultants 
1.  Team Leader/Water Sector Specialist (international, 7.5 person-months) 
11.  The  consultant  will  be  an  experienced  international  expert  with  qualifications  and 
specialization  in  a  range  of  water  resources  development  areas,  with  significant  relevant 
experience in Viet Nam. He/she should have a sound knowledge of and practical experience in 
IWRM, the ecological principle establishing river basins as the basis of IWRM, ideally with 
experience  in  international  river  basin  management,  and  familiarity  with  a  wide  range  of 
technical issues related to irrigation, flood management, rural and urban water supply and 
sanitation, water quality, waste treatment, and environmental and ecosystem sustainability. 
He/she will have undertaken similar reviews and led teams of diverse backgrounds. He/she will 
have strong interpersonal and communication skills, be completely fluent in written and spoken 
English, and have proven ability in report writing for professional purposes. Recent experience 
in Viet Nam is essential, as is a good understanding of the present policy and institutional 
setting affecting the water sector. He/she will have had substantial professional experience in 
developing countries.

12  Appendix 3 
2.  Water Policy/Institutional Specialist (international, 3.5 person-months) 
12.  The  consultant  will  be  an  experienced  international  expert  with  qualifications  and 
specialization in a range of water policy, strategy, and water resources institutions development, 
with significant relevant experience in Viet Nam. He/she should have a sound knowledge of and 
practical experience in IWRM and the ecological principle establishing river basins as the basis 
of IWRM. Recent experience in Viet Nam is essential, as is a good understanding of the present 
policy and institutional setting affecting the water sector. He/she will have had professional 
experience in developing countries. 
 
3.  Natural Resource/Development Economist (international, 2.0 person-months) 
13.  The  consultant  will  be  an  experienced  international  expert  with  qualifications  and 
specialization in natural resources economics. He/she should have a sound knowledge of and 
practical  experience  in  analysis  of  IWRM  investments.  He/she  will  have  had  professional 
experience in developing countries, with recent experience in Viet Nam. 
 
4.  Disaster Management Specialist (international, 1.5 person-months) 
14.  The  consultant  will  be  an  experienced  international  expert  with  qualifications  and 
specialization  in  natural  resources  management  and  institutional  development  for  disaster 
management. He/she should have a sound knowledge of and practical experience in disaster 
management in Viet Nam or similar environments. He/she will have had professional experience 
in developing countries. 
 
5.  Irrigation Specialist3 (international, 5.0 person-months) 
15.  The  consultant  will  be  an  experienced  international  expert  with  qualifications  and 
specialization in irrigation, civil, or agricultural engineering with significant relevant experience in 
Viet Nam. He/she should have a sound knowledge of and practical experience in irrigation 
development  and  management,  including  issues  of  investment  effectiveness,  water 
management efficiency, management transfer, and sustainable financing of operations and 
maintenance. He/she will have had professional experience in developing countries, with recent 
experience in Viet Nam. 
 
E.  National Consultants 
16.  A team of national water resources specialists, familiar with the status of implementation 
of the national water resources strategy (NWRS), will be engaged from a firm/nongovernment 
organization (NGO)/research institute to undertake specific sector assessments under the TA 
work plan in close collaboration with the counterpart agency task force under the supervision of 
the consultant team leader. The team will consist of (i) a water policy specialist/co-team leader 
(8.0 person-months), (ii) a water resources specialist (5.5 person-months), (iii) a groundwater 
specialist (3.5 person-months), (iv) a water quality specialist (3.5 person-months), (v) a rural 
sociologist  (4.5  person-months),  (vi)  a  disaster  management  (3.5  person-months),  (vii)  a   
industrial water management specialist (3.5 person-months), (viii) an economist (5.0 person-
months), (ix) an environment specialist (4.0 person-months), (x) an energy sector specialist 
(4.0 person-months), (xi) a river navigation specialist (3.5 person-months), (xii) a water supply 
and sanitation specialist (3.5 person-months), (xiii) a Geographic Information Systems (GIS) 
and data management specialist (5.5 person-months), and (xiv) a monitoring and evaluation 
                                                 
3  The World Bank is responsible for selecting and funding the irrigation specialist for a total of not less than 5 person-
months. Once the consultant team has been fielded, the irrigation specialist will report to the team leader for all 
technical matters, reporting, and day-to-day coordination.

Appendix 3  13 
specialist (4.0 person-months). A further 8 person-months of national specialist input remains to 
be allocated following project inception phase. All national consultants will have experience of 
working with international consultants and will be fluent in written and spoken English. A proven 
ability in report writing is essential for all positions. 
 
F.  Reporting 
17.  An inception report will be presented within 1 month of the start of the Review. The draft 
status report will be prepared within about 3 months of the start of the Review. It will be 
presented at a national workshop after a suitable period of review by different stakeholders. A 
final status report will be presented within 1 month of the workshop.  
 
18.  The issues and options working paper will be submitted for review 2 months after the 
final status report has been submitted. It will form the basis for consultations with relevant 
stakeholders on the recommendations. The draft final report will be prepared 3 months after the 
issues  and  options  working  paper  has  been  submitted.  It  will  be  presented  at  a  national 
workshop after a suitable period of review by different stakeholders. The final report will be 
presented within 1 month of the final national workshop and will include an agreed set of 
recommendations. Monthly progress reports will be submitted to the task force.

14  Appendix 4 
 
 
OUTLINE OF THE VIET NAM WATER SECTOR REVIEW FINAL REPORT 
 
1.   The final report will include, inter alia, the following sections: 
 
    EXECUTIVE SUMMARY  
 
I.   INTRODUCTION  
The chapter will describe the rationale and approach adopted for the 2007 Water 
Sector Review. 
 
II.   DEVELOPMENT CONTEXT AND NATIONAL GOALS TO 2020  
The chapter will provide a review of the national development plan, national goals, 
demographic, social, environmental, and economic projections as these relate to 
water sector. 
 
III.   WATER RESOURCES ASSESSMENT 
Provides  an  overview  of  water  resources  of  Viet  Nam,  and  includes  inter  alia 
(i) descriptions of the topography and climate; (ii) spatial and temporal distribution of 
surface water resources; (iii) groundwater resources; (iv) assessment of the extent 
and  location  of  water  quality  problems  with  respect  to  industrial,  human,  and 
agricultural effluents, saline intrusion, and water shed degradation; and (v) projected 
changes to the water resources caused by climate change. A description of the data 
available  to  the  water  sector  review  and  an  assessment  of  data  quality  and 
coverage will be included. 
 
IV.   ASSESSMENT OF WATER SECTOR STATUS  
The chapter will provide an assessment of the present patterns of resource use; the 
legal, policy, and institutional environment in which water resources are managed; 
state-of-the-art examples of water management experiences from a wide range of 
programs and projects; and a preliminary analysis of the economic significance of 
water at household and national levels. The status report will include assessments 
of subsectors, including (i) agricultural water use; (ii) rural and urban water supply 
and  sanitation;  (iii)  industrial  water  use  and  waste  water  management; 
(iv) groundwater  management;  (v)  inland  navigation;  (vi)  hydropower  use; 
(vii) water-related  disasters;  and  (viii)  environment  and  ecosystem  water 
requirements, including tourism and recreation. Crosscutting themes will include 
gender and poverty dimensions in the water sector. This chapter will include the 
outputs  of  the  multi-stakeholder  workshop  organized  to  review  the  subsector 
analysis. 
 
The  assessment  will  review  current  conditions  and  recent  trends;  and  identify 
management and development issues and priorities. The chapter will include an 
analysis of the opportunities and threats that currently face the water sector. 
 
V.   ISSUES AND OPTIONS  
The chapter will present an analysis of the strengths and weaknesses of options 
that will help the Government of Viet Nam achieve the vision for the water sector set 
out  in  the  National  Water  Resources  Strategy  (NWRS)  by  addressing  the 
opportunities and threats identified in the previous chapter’s assessment of the 
current water sector.

Appendix 4  15 
 
VI.  WATER SECTOR INVESTMENTS AND PRIORITIES 
The chapter will present a draft road map of investments to implement the NWRS 
over the next 10–15 years, including (i) policy, regulatory, and legal reforms to 
overcome  bottlenecks;  (ii)  investments  in  urban  and  rural  water  supply  and 
sanitation;  (iii)  industrial  water  supply  and  waste  water/pollution  control; 
(iv) agricultural  water  management,  including  management  transfer;  (v)  flood 
management,  control  of  saline  intrusion;  (vi)  groundwater  management  and 
regulation;  (vii)  hydropower;  and  (viii)  navigation  and  environmental  flow 
management. 
 
VII.   RECOMMENDED ACTIONS
